description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

Danish authorities announced on June 18 that the country will introduce a new regional model for their travel restrictions/recommendations for the EU and Schengen (and UK) countries.
Effective June 27, EU and Schengen countries will be categorized as either open/yellow (åbent) or quarantine country/orange (karantæneland) depending on its level of coronavirus spread.

An orange is those that report a level of 30 infected citizens /100 000 citizens or higher, and for travelers entering Denmark from a quarantine country, the Danish authorities strongly encourage a self-isolation period of 14 days. 
The list of orange countries will be updated on a weekly basis as of June 27 2020.

description:
Danish authorities announced on June 18 that the country will introduce a new regional model for their travel restrictions/recommendations for the EU and Schengen (and UK) countries.
Effective June 27, EU and Schengen countries will be categorized as either open/yellow (åbent) or quarantine country/orange (karantæneland) depending on its level of coronavirus spread. 
To be categorized as yellow, the country needs to report a level of under 20 infected citizens/ 100 000 citizens. 
An orange is those that report a level of 30 infected citizens /100 000 citizens or higher, and for travelers entering Denmark from a quarantine country, the Danish authorities strongly encourage a self-isolation period of 14 days. 
The list of orange countries will be updated on a weekly basis as of June 27 2020. UPDATE: As of December 12 2020, Danish authorities will provide travelers with more detailed travel restrictions/recommendations as regions inside an orange/yellow country can be classified as low vs high risk, which in practice thus allows traveling to yellow regions in orange countries.
The recommendations for travelers returning/entering Denmark from an orange country or region has also changed, from 14 days to 10 days of self-isolation, which can be ended at the 5th day on providing a negative Covid-19 test result.

description: The National Board of Health has updated the general recommendations for how to prevent the spread of infection with new coronavirus. The recommendations now also contain information on the use of face masks in certain situations. On the basis of the WHO s recommendations, the National Board of Health has reassessed the use of masks. The assessment remains that one can generally move in public space without wearing a mask. However, there are some special situations where one can not comply with the general recommendations and where a barrier protection, such as mask, can be used instead. The situations where wearing of mask is now recommended are  If you are infected or have symptoms of COVID-19 and need to break your self-isolation to transport yourself to and from the hospital; If you are on your way home from, for example, the airport after a trip in a high-risk area abroad and need self-isolation; If you are in close contact with someone who is infected and needs to break self-isolation to transport you to and from tests; If you are a relative and cannot keep your distance from a person at increased risk, eg when in need of care and attention.
